{{About|the pan-Arab Ba'ath Party, which is Iraqi-led but has branches in multiple countries|the Ba'ath Party's regional branch established in 1951|Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Iraq Region}} {{Infobox political party |name=Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party |native_name=حزب البعث العربي الاشتراكي |colorcode={{Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Iraq Region/meta/color}} |general_secretary=[[Izzat Ibrahim al-Douri]] |foundation={{Start date|1968|02}} |split=[[Ba'ath Party]] (unitary) |dissolved={{End date|2003|05|01}}
(national leadership stopped functioning{{fact|date=February 2018}}, but regional chapters still active) |headquarters=[[Baghdad]], Iraq (until 2003) |newspaper= |membership_year= |ideology=[[Arab nationalism]]
[[Ba'athism]] |flag=[[File:Flag of the Ba'ath Party.svg|200px|border]] |colors=Black, red, white and green ([[Pan-Arab colors]]) |seats1_title=[[House of Representatives (Jordan)]] |seats1={{Composition bar|1|130|hex={{Ba'ath Party/meta/color}}}} |website= |footnotes=}} The '''Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party''' (spelled "Ba'th" or "Baath", "resurrection" or "renaissance"; {{lang-ar|حزب البعث العربي الاشتراكي}} ''Ḥizb Al-Ba'aṯ Al-'Arabī Al-Ištirākī''), also referred to as the pro-Iraqi Ba'ath movement, is a [[Ba'athism|Ba'athist]] [[political party]] which was headquartered in [[Baghdad]], [[Iraq]] until 2003. It is one of two parties (with identical names) which emerged from the [[1966 Syrian coup d'état|1966 split]] of the original [[Ba'ath Party]]. In 1966, the original Ba'ath Party was split in half; one half was led by the [[Damascus]] leadership of the Ba'ath Party which [[Ba'ath Party (Syrian-dominated faction)|established a party in Syria]] and the other half with its leadership in Baghdad. Both Ba'ath parties retained the same name and maintained parallel structures in the [[Arab world]], but became so antagonistic that Syria—led by its [[Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Syria Region|Ba'ath Party]]—became the only Arab state to support [[Iran]] against Iraq during the bloody [[Iran–Iraq War]]. The Ba'athists [[Ramadan Revolution|seized power]] in Iraq for the first time in 1963, but were [[November 1963 Iraqi coup d'état|deposed]] several months later. The party's regional organisation governed Iraq between 1968 and 2003, for many years under the leadership of [[Saddam Hussein]]. The [[Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Iraq Region]] was banned in 2003 by the [[Coalition Provisional Authority]] following the [[2003 invasion of Iraq|invasion of Iraq]]. ==Structure== {{Ba'athism sidebar}} ===Secretary-Generals=== *[[Michel Aflaq]] (1968–1989) *Vacant (1989–1992) *[[Saddam Hussein]] (1992–2006) *[[Izzat Ibrahim al-Douri]] (2007–present) ===National Congress=== Note: for the 1st–8th National Congresses, see the national congresses held by the unified, pre-February 1966 Ba'ath Party. *9th National Congress (February 1968) *10th National Congress (March 1970) *11th National Congress (1977) *12th National Congress (1992) ===Organization=== Following the [[1966 Syrian coup d'état]], which overthrew the Aflaqite faction led by [[Michel Aflaq]], [[Salah al-Din al-Bitar]], [[Munif al-Razzaz]] and others, the [[Ba'ath Party|original Ba'ath Party]] split into Iraqi-dominated and [[Ba'ath Party (Syrian-dominated faction)|a Syrian-dominated ba'ath movements]]. The two movements established separate National Commands; the National Command was in theory the highest party body in both movements and controlled their respective ba'athist movements. However, in both countries the National Command was under the control of its respective Regional Command. In the Iraqi-dominated Ba'ath movement, all National Command members came from their regional branch—for instance, there was always a member representing the Ba'ath Party branch in Jordan.{{cite book | author = Metz, Helen Chapin | pages = [https://books.google.com/books?id=X4bt8oiR_50C&pg=PA191 191–192] | title = Iraq: A Country Study | location = | publisher = [[Kessinger Publishing]] | year = 2004 | isbn = 1-4191-2671-7}} In theory, the National Command was the highest party organ between national congresses,{{cite book | author = Ali, Tariq | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=GKwJ7RhON3sC&pg=PA106 106] | title = Bush in Babylon: The Recolonisation of Iraq | volume = | publisher = [[Verso Paper|Verso]] | year = 2004 | isbn = 1-84467-512-2}} with the power to control the affairs of Regional Commands in other regions (countries).{{cite book|title=Historical Dictionary of Iraq|first1=Edmund A.|last1=Ghareeb|first2=Beth K.|last2=Dougherty|publisher=The Scarecrow Press, Ltd|year=2004|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=RIB5qT9sGnwC&pg=PA192 192]|isbn= 978-0-8108-4330-1}} Delegates to a National Congress elected the members of the National Command, who were eligible for reelection. While the National Command had few ''[[de facto]]'' powers, many of its leading members also held seats in the [[Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Iraq Region|Iraqi Regional Command]] and the [[Revolutionary Command Council (Iraq)|Revolutionary Command Council]].{{cite book|title=Historical Dictionary of Iraq|first1=Edmund A.|last1=Ghareeb|first2=Beth K.|last2=Dougherty|publisher=The Scarecrow Press, Ltd|year=2004|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=RIB5qT9sGnwC&pg=PA169 169]|isbn= 978-0-8108-4330-1}} Aflaq was elected Secretary-General of the National Command at the Ninth National Congress, held in February 1968 in Beirut, Lebanon, by the Iraqi-dominated Ba'ath Party.{{cite book | author = Kostiner, Joseph | title = Conflict and Cooperation in the Gulf Region | publisher = VS Verlag | year = 1998 | isbn = 3-531-16205-5 |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=YQb1Ilj2U7EC&pg=PA36 36]}} He retained his post until his death in 1989, when he was succeeded by [[Saddam Hussein]].{{cite book | author = Moubayed, Sami M. | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=sC–xU8QHSooC&pg=PA347 347] | title = Steel & Silk: Men and Women who shaped Syria 1900–2000 | publisher = Cune Press | year = 2006 | isbn = 978-1-885942-40-1}} After Saddam was executed on 30 December 2006, [[Izzat Ibrahim al-Douri]] became ''de facto'' leader of the Ba'ath Party on 3 January 2007. As Secretary of the Iraqi Regional Command of the Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party, he is the highest-ranked surviving member of the former Ba'ath party. ==Branches by region== ===Algeria=== {{main|Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party of Algeria}} The party branch in Algeria, the Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party of Algeria ({{lang-ar|حزب البعث العربي الاشتراكي في الجزائر}} ''Hizb Al-Ba'ath Al-'Arabi Al-Ishtiraki fi Al-Jaza'ir''; [[French language|French]]: ''Parti Baath arabe socialiste d'Algérie''), is led by Ahmed Choutri (secretary of the Regional Command). The party is banned and Choutri was forced to flee to Iraq during the 1990s because of governmental repression against the Algerian Ba'ath movement. The party sympathises with the Iraqi ba'athist insurgency and supports [[Izzat Ibrahim al-Douri]], leader of the Iraqi branch. Following his return to Algeria in 2003, Choutri wrote ''The Baathist Faith of President Saddam''.{{cite web | author = Belamry, Algiers-Ramada | url = http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2008/09/08/56229.html | title = Baath Party resumes underground activities | location = | publisher = alarabiya.net | date = 8 September 2008 | accessdate = 10 July 2013 }} ===Bahrain=== {{main|Nationalist Democratic Assembly}} The Nationalist Democratic Assembly ({{Lang-ar|التجمع القومي الديمقراطي|rtl=yes}}, {{lang|ar-Latn|Al-Tajamu'u Al-Qawmi Al-Dimuqratiyah}}) represents the Iraqi-dominated Ba'ath Party in [[Bahrain]].{{cite web | author = Mahdi, Mazdi | url = http://www.thenational.ae/news/world/middle-east/bahrainis-take-to-the-streets-over-job-security | title = Bahrainis take to the streets over job security | work = [[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]] | date = 2 May 2010 | accessdate = 26 February 2012 }} The group is led by Hassan Ali as Secretary General and Mahmoud Kassab as Deputy Secretary General.{{cite web | author = [[Staff writer]] | url = http://www.al-qawmi.org/?categoryid=12 |trans-title=Nationalist Democratic Assembly | script-title=ar:التجمع القومي الديمقراطي | publisher = Nationalist Democratic Assembly | date = 15 November 2007 | accessdate = 26 February 2012 | language = Arabic }} It was established by Bahrainis who had studied in [[History of Iraq (1968–2003)|Ba'athist Iraq]] during the 1960s and 1970s. The party boycotted the [[Bahraini parliamentary election, 2002|2002 parliamentary election]], but not the [[Bahraini parliamentary election, 2006|2006 election]].{{cite web | author = [[Staff writer]] | url = http://www.alwasatnews.com/index.php?plugin=elections&act=read&id=51 |trans-title=Nationalist Democratic Assembly | script-title=ar:جمعية التجمع القومي الديمقراطي | work = [[Al-Wasat (Bahraini newspaper)|Al-Wasat]] | date = 15 November 2007 | accessdate = 26 February 2012 | language = Arabic }} The [[Bahraini parliamentary by-election, 2011|2011 parliamentary by-election]] was boycotted by the party in solidarity with the [[Bahraini uprising (2011–present)|Bahraini uprising]].{{cite web | author = [[Staff writer]] | url = http://www.alwasatnews.com/index.php?plugin=elections&act=read&id=51 |trans-title=National Rally fifth Association announces boycott of the elections complementary | script-title=ar:"التجمع القومي" خامس جمعية تعلن مقاطعتها للانتخابات التكميلية | work = [[Al-Wasat (Bahraini newspaper)|Al-Wasat]] | date = 16 August 2011 | accessdate = 26 February 2012 | language = Arabic }} It is headquartered in [[Zinj, Bahrain|Zinj]].{{cite web |url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/1583/news/read/209453/1.html |title=Attorney Calls for further investigation into the incident |language=Arabic |trans-title="النيابة" تطلب مواصلة التحري في حادث "الزنج" |work=[[Al-Wasat (Bahraini newspaper)|Al-Wasat]] |accessdate=10 April 2013}} The party opposes the government's [[naturalisation|naturalisation policies]] and contends that it is unfair for ethnic Bahrainis to compete equally with foreign workers for jobs. The Nationalist Democratic Assembly remains pro-Saddam Hussein and according to its webpage supports the [[Arab Spring]].{{cite web | author = [[Staff writer]] | url = http://www.al-qawmi.org/?categoryid=13 |trans-title=News | script-title=ar:أخبار | publisher = Nationalist Democratic Assembly | date = 15 November 2007 | accessdate = 26 February 2012 | language = Arabic }} It opposed the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]], considering it an act of brutality against the Iraqi people.{{cite web | author = [[Staff writer]] | url = http://www.ahewar.org/debat/show.art.asp?aid=6449 |trans-title=Statement issued by the Nationalist Democratic Assembly | script-title=ar:بيان صادر عن التجمع القومي الديمقراطي في العراق | publisher = Ahewar.org | date = 28 March 2003 | accessdate = 26 February 2012 | language = Arabic }} The party actively supports the overthrow of the [[Al Khalifa family|existing monarchy]], with a peaceful transition to democracy.{{cite web | author = [[Staff writer]] | url = http://www.islamtimes.org/vdcjyoevxuqetxz.3ffu.html |trans-title=Democratic Rally: Do not drop the slogan of the system due to certain circumstances | script-title=ar:التجمع الديمقراطي: عدم رفع شعار إسقاط النظام سببه ظروف معينة | publisher = Islamtimes.org | date = | accessdate = 26 February 2012 | language = Arabic }} ===Egypt=== {{main|Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Egypt Region}} The Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Egypt Region ({{lang-ar|حزب البعث العربي الاشتراكي- مصر}} ''Hizb Al-Ba'ath Al-Arabi Al-Ishtiraki – Misr'') is an active branch in Egypt. The party supports the removing of [[Bashar al-Assad]] of Syria, although calls for no foreign intervention in the [[Syrian Civil War|conflict]], whether by Israel, Turkey or Iran, as the party believes all such countries have ulterior motives and seek to undermine Syria.{{cite news |title=The statement of the Arab Baath Socialist Party of Egyptian on the aggression against Syria |url=http://www.aladhwaa.net/?ac=3&no=6445&d_f=10&t_f=0&t=5&lang_in=Ar |newspaper=Aladhwaa |date=7 May 2013 |accessdate=5 July 2013}} The party was outlawed in the early 1990s and two Iraqi Intelligence Officials were detained on 14 April 1991 with $38,000 in their possession, money which the Egyptian authorities claimed was to be used to fund sabotage operations in Egypt.{{cite news |title=Two Iraqi Plotters Detained |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1309&dat=19910414&id=GsFUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=VZADAAAAIBAJ&pg=4831,5537593 |newspaper=New Strait Times |date=15 April 1991 |accessdate=20 July 2013}} Several other Egyptian Ba'athists, including the poet [[Muhammad Afifi Matar]], were also detained in April 1991 on suspicion of involvement in an Iraqi terrorist plot.{{cite book |last=Mickolus |first=Edward F. |title=The Terrorist List: The Middle East, Volume 1 A-K |url=https://books.google.com/?id=dj_UiuHRT1IC&pg=PA405&dq=afifi+matar#v=onepage&q=afifi%20matar&f=false Edward Mickolus, 2009 |accessdate= |year=2009 |publisher=ABC-CLIO |location= |isbn= |page=405}} ===Eritrea=== Ba'athist organizations emerged in the leadership of the [[Eritrean Liberation Front]] in the 1970s, with pro-Baghdad and pro-Damascus groups competing for political dominance over the front. This split contributed to the downfall of the ELF and the emergence of the [[Eritrean People's Liberation Front]] as the dominant liberation movement.{{cite book|author=Awet Tewelde Weldemichael|title=Third World Colonialism and Strategies of Liberation: Eritrea and East Timor Compared|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T4ctMMpBfFkC&pg=PA155|year=2013|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-107-03123-4|page=155}} A key pro-Iraqi Ba'athist was Abdel Gadir Jeilani, who became the leader of the ELF-PLF-Revolutionary Council in the 1980s.{{cite book|author=Alexander De Waal|title=Evil Days: Thirty Years of War and Famine in Ethiopia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RcVFXUwraxsC&pg=PA252|year=1991|publisher=Human Rights Watch|isbn=978-1-56432-038-4|page=252}} ===Iraq=== {{main|Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Iraq Region}} In Iraq, the Ba'ath party remained a civilian group and lacked strong support from the military. The party had little impact and the movement split into several factions after 1958 and again in 1966. The movement was reported to have lacked strong popular support,[[The Economist]], London, 24–30 June 1978, p. 78. but through the construction of a strong party apparatus the party succeeded in gaining power. The Iraqi-based party was originally committed to pan-Arabism (like its Syrian counterpart). After taking power in 1968, the party adopted [[Iraqi nationalism]] and encouraging [[Iraqis]] to identify themselves as cultural heirs of Mesopotamia with a medieval-Islamic identity.Alexander J. Motyl. ''Encyclopedia of Nationalism: Leaders, Movements, and Concepts, Volume II''. Academic Press, 2001. Pp. 240. Saddam Hussein sought to be seen as leader of a great, neo-Mesopotamian Iraqi nation by having himself compared to [[Nebuchadnezzar II]] and [[Hammurabi]]. In June 2003, the [[Coalition Provisional Authority]] (CPA) banned the Ba'ath party. The additional step the CPA took—banning all members of the top four tiers of the Ba'ath Party from the new government, [[Public school (government funded)|public schools]] and colleges—was criticized for blocking too many experienced people from participation in the new government. Thousands were removed from their positions, including doctors, professors, schoolteachers and bureaucrats. Many teachers lost their jobs, sparking protests at schools and universities. Under previous Ba'ath-party rule, one could not reach a high position in the government or a school without becoming a party member and party membership was a prerequisite for university admission. While many Ba'athists joined for ideological reasons, many more were members because it was a way to better their options. Following pressure by the United States, the policy of [[de-Ba'athification]] was addressed by the Iraqi government in January 2008 with its controversial [[Accountability and Justice Act]]. This purported to ease the policy, but many feared it would lead to further dismissals.{{cite news | first=Amit R. | last=Paley |author2=Joshua Partlow | title=Iraq's New Law on Ex-Baathists Could Bring Another Purge | date=23 January 2008 | work=[[The Washington Post]] | url =https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/01/22/AR2008012203538.html | pages = | accessdate = 26 November 2011 }} The Ba'ath Party is led by Saddam's former deputy [[Izzat Ibrahim al-Douri]]. ===Jordan=== {{main|Jordanian Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party}} At the time of the 1966 split, the Jordanian branch had an estimated 1,000 members.{{cite book | author = Goldman, Ralph Morris | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=yJWlDYuoT5sC&pg=PA60 60] | title = The Future Catches Up: Transnational Parties and Democracy | location = | publisher = [[iUniverse]] | year = 2002 | isbn = 978-0-595-22888-1}} It was active in the [[#Palestine|Arab Liberation Front]] (ALF) and the ALF's first leader was the Jordanian, Zaid Haydar. [[Munif al-Razzaz]], who joined the pro-Iraqi Ba'ath resistance in 1966, eventually became an ALF leader. From there, he climbed the party ladder and became a member of the National Command before he was placed under [[house arrest]] by Iraqi authorities. Shahir Abu Shahut became the first leader of the party branch in Jordan after the 1966 split. Since the establishment of the authoritarian political systems in Iraq and Syria, the popularity of the Ba'ath Party has waned, but Ba'athist ideology remains popular. The reason being that both Ba'ath parties (the pro-Iraqi and the pro-Syrian) have replaced ideology with blind allegiance to [[Saddamism|Saddamist discourse]] or the [[al-Assad family|al-Assad rule]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cablegatesearch.net/cable.php?id=05AMMAN7597&q=baath |title= The Baath Party In Jordan: Short On Funds And Members Madaba |publisher=[[Cablegate]] |date=22 September 2005 |accessdate=10 July 2013}} A Jordanese academic, talking to the American embassy in Amman, Jordan, said that "there are far more real Baathists outside the party than inside", noting that the present party is downplaying (and even replacing) ideological components to get more followers. The party was able to gain some support in the 1990s because of its status as a Ba'ath Party branch and it was able to help finance thousands of scholarships to Iraqi universities. However, with the 2003 invasion of Iraq the party was nearly forced into bankruptcy and lost most of its followers when it failed to finance the return of students from Iraq. The Ba'ath branch was denied legal registration in 1992.{{cite book | author = [[Staff writer]] | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=v49mVUoTHMoC&pg=PA79 79] | title = Jordan in Transition | location = | publisher = [[Palgrave Macmillan]] | year = 2002 | isbn = 978-0-312-29538-7}} The party was legally registered in 1993, but forced to change its name from the Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party to the Jordanian Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party ({{lang-ar|حزب البعث العربي الاشتراكي الاردني}} ''Hizb Al-Ba'ath Al-'Arabi Al-Ishtiraki Al-Urduniy'').{{cite book | author = Day, Alan John | page = [https://books.google.com/books?ei=qAryTq–KONH54QTk8fTPAQ&hl=no&id=pmwYAAAAIAAJ&dq=%22al–Baath%22+Jordan&q=JASBP#search_anchor 280] | title = Political parties in the World | location = | publisher = [[University of Michigan]] | year = 2002 | isbn = 0-9536278-7-X}} Khalil Haddadeen, Jordan's former minister of information, was elected to Parliament during the [[Jordanian general election, 1993|1993]] and [[Jordanian general election, 1997|1997 elections]] on a [[Saddamism|pro-Iraqi, Saddamist platform]].{{cite book | author = Schenker, David Kenneth | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=6ugoeXU4UnQC&pg=PA19 19] | title = Dancing with Saddam: The Strategic Tango of Jordanian–Iraqi Relations | location = | publisher = [[Lexington Books]] | year = 2003 | isbn = 0-7391-0649-X}} Currently, the Ba'ath branch has no members of parliament. In its first regional congress since the 2003 invasion of Iraq, the Regional Command alleged it would publicize an alleged letter from Saddam Hussien. However, the Jordanian press largely ignored the event. Today, in contrast to Ba'athist ideology both the pro-Iraq and pro-Syrian Ba'ath branches are considered largely irrelevant in the Jordanian political scene. It is suffering from financial problems and it is criticized by religious Jordanians for its [[secularism]], while others are weary of its Arab nationalist ideology. In a 1995 poll, 16.8 percent of Jordanians said they were aware that the Iraqi Ba'ath branch existed, making the Ba'ath branch the third-best-known political party in Jordan (surpassing the [[Ba'ath Arab Progressive Party]], the Syrian Ba'athist branch, by over 10 percent in the poll).{{cite book | author = [[Staff writer]] | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=v49mVUoTHMoC&pg=PA120 120] | title = Jordan in Transition | location = | publisher = [[Palgrave Macmillan]] | year = 2002 | isbn = 978-0-312-29538-7}} In 2003 it was estimated that the party had less than 200 members.{{cite web|url=http://www.cablegatesearch.net/cable.php?id=03AMMAN2989&q=ba-th |title= Jordan's Political Parties: Islamists, Leftists, Nationalists And Centrists |publisher=[[Cablegate]] |date=20 May 2003 |accessdate=10 July 2013}} According to a [[Cablegate]] document dating back to 2007, the Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party figure Ahmed Al Dmour was considered one of the biggest threats to [[Islamic Action Front]] dominance on the political scene.{{cite web|url=http://www.cablegatesearch.net/cable.php?id=07AMMAN3162&q=ba-ath |title=Jordanian Municipal Elections: The Islamist - Government Showdowns In Irbid, Karak, And Madaba |publisher=[[Cablegate]] |date=26 July 2007 |accessdate=10 July 2013}} ===Kuwait=== {{Expand section|date=June 2014}} As of 1983 the branch was led by Faisal al-Sani.{{cite book |last=al-Mdaires |first=Falah Abdullah |date= |title=Islamic Extremism in Kuwait: From the Muslim Brotherhood to Al-Qaeda and other Islamic Political Groups |url= |location= |publisher=Routledge |isbn= |accessdate= |page=217 |year=2010}} The Kuwaiti Ba'ath Party branch collapsed during [[Gulf War]] because of the [[Invasion of Kuwait|Iraqi invasion of Kuwait]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cablegatesearch.net/cable.php?id=10KUWAIT42&q=baath|title= Kuwait Receives Iraqi Political Figures In Run-up To Parliamentary Elections |publisher=[[Cablegate]] |date=20 January 2010 |accessdate=10 July 2013}} [[Saleh al-Mutlaq]], the leader of the [[Iraqi National Dialogue Front]], has been accused of trying to rebuild the party. ===Lebanon=== {{main|Socialist Arab Lebanon Vanguard Party}} It is presently known as the Socialist Arab Lebanon Vanguard Party ({{lang-ar|حزب طليعة لبنان العربي الاشتراكي|rtl=yes}}, {{lang|ar-Latn|Hizb Al-Taliyeh Lubnan Al-'Arabi Al-Ishtiraki}}). It is the party branch in Lebanon. The branch held its second congress in October 2011.{{cite web| author = Socialist Lebanon Vanguard Party | publisher = Second Congress of the Socialist Lebanon Vanguard Party. Almansore.com | script-title=ar:التقرير السياسي الصادر عن المؤتمر الثاني لحزب طليعة لبنان العربي الاشتراكي ( السابع عشر ) |trans-title=Political Report of the Second Congress of the Party, the Socialist Arab Lebanon Vanguard (XVII) | date = 29 December 2010 | accessdate = 18 February 2012 | language = Arabic | url = http://www.almansore.com/Art.php?id=21811 }} However, the existence of the pro-Iraqi Lebanese branch of the Ba'ath party has much longer roots. Following the 1966 split in the Ba'ath movement with party members split between Syrian and Iraqi allegiances, the Iraqi wing was led by Abd al-Majid Rafei.Solh, Raghid El-. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=49z7AFqIE2IC&pg=PA331 Lebanon and Arabism]''. London: I. B. Tauris in association with the Centre for Lebanese Studies, 2004. p. 331Rabinovich, Itamar, and Itamar Rabinovich. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=2PbLcYdLUgsC&pg=PA79 The War for Lebanon, 1970-1985]''. Ithaca: Cornell University Press, 1985. p. 79 Other prominent members at the time of the split were Jihad George Karam, Rafiq Nasib Alfaqiya, Karam Mohamed Assahli, Hani Mohamed Shoiab, Ammar Mohamed Shabli, Hassan Khalil Gharib and Asaf Habin Alharakat.{{cite web| author = [[Staff writer]] | publisher= Lebanon Knowledge Development Gateway |trans-title=Political society as the "vanguard party, Arab Socialist Party of Lebanon | script-title=ar:جمعية سياسية باسم "حزب طليعة لبنان العربي الاشتراكي" | date = | accessdate = 18 February 2012 | language = Arabic | url = http://lkdg.org/ar/node/1146 }} At first, the pro-Iraqi Ba'ath branch and the [[Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Lebanon Region|pro-Syrian Ba'ath branch]] worked side-by-side in the National Front, but with tension increasing between the Syrian and Iraqi Ba'athist factions the two parties were on a war footing.{{cite book | author = Rabinovich, Itamar | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=2PbLcYdLUgsC&pg=PA79 79] | title = The war for Lebanon, 1970–1985 | publisher = [[Cornell University Press]] | year = 1985 | isbn = 978-0-8014-9313-3}} The party was active in 1960s demonstrations{{cite book | author = El-Khazen, Farid | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=TQdheeeXQCgC&pg=PA143 143] | title = The Breakdown of the State in Lebanon, 1967–1976 | publisher = [[Harvard University Press]] | year = 2000 | isbn = 978-0-674-08105-5}} and al-Rafei was detained by Lebanese authorities for his political activities,{{cite book | author = El-Khazen, Farid | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=TQdheeeXQCgC&pg=PA144 144] | title = The Breakdown of the State in Lebanon, 1967–1976 | publisher = [[Harvard University Press]] | year = 2000 | isbn = 978-0-674-08105-5}} but he was a candidate from [[Lebanese general election, 1968 in Tripoli City|Tripoli in the 1968 general election]].{{cite book | author = Zumiyya, Jamal | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=NZo3AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA106 106] | title = The parliamentary election of Lebanon 1968 | publisher = [[Brill Publishers|BRILL Archive]] | year = 1972 | volume = 2 | isbn =}} The party expanded during the first half of the 1970s{{cite book | author = El-Khazen, Farid | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=TQdheeeXQCgC&pg=PA74 74] | title = The Breakdown of the State in Lebanon, 1967–1976 | publisher = [[Harvard University Press]] | year = 2000 | isbn = 978-0-674-08105-5}} and in the [[Lebanese general election, 1972|1972 general election]] al-Rafi was elected to parliament from Tripoli.{{cite book|title = Political parties of the Middle East and North Africa | publisher = [[Greenwood Press]] | author = Tachau, Frank | year = 1994 | isbn = 978-0-313-26649-2 | page = [https://books.google.com/books?ei=sARAT–r_DKbd4QSkyKioCA&hl=no&id=OEOLAAAAMAAJ&dq=%22Abdel+Majib+al–Rafi%22&q=%22al–Rafi%22#search_anchor 307] }} Ali al-Khalil, a former member, was elected from Tyre. The party was active in [[Southern Lebanon]] and was built with generous aid from Iraq.{{cite book | author = El-Khazen, Farid | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=TQdheeeXQCgC&pg=PA198 198] | title = The Breakdown of the State in Lebanon, 1967–1976 | publisher = [[Harvard University Press]] | year = 2000 | isbn = 978-0-674-08105-5}} During the [[Lebanese Civil War]], the Lebanese parliament formed the National Dialogue Committee in 1975. [[Assem Qanso]] of the [[Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party of Lebanon|pro-Syrian Ba'ath Party]] became a member, but no figures from the pro-Iraqi Ba'ath Party were given a seat on the committee.{{cite book | author = El-Khazen, Farid | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=TQdheeeXQCgC&pg=PA316 316] | title = The Breakdown of the State in Lebanon, 1967–1976 | publisher = [[Harvard University Press]] | year = 2000 | isbn = 978-0-674-08105-5}} Tahsein al-Atrash, leader of the Ba'ath branch at the time, was shot dead in November 1981.{{cite book | author = O'Ballance, Edgar | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=iZhJgTkW058C&pg=PA111 111] | title = Civil war in Lebanon, 1975–92 | publisher = [[Palgrave Macmillan]] | year = 1998 | isbn = 978-0-312-21593-4}} The party was a member of the [[Lebanese National Movement]], a political organisation led by [[Walid Jumblatt]] of the [[Progressive Socialist Party]].{{cite book | author = Cassese, Antonio | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=0jNCMwZN2c4C&pg=PA205 205] | title = The Current Legal Regulation of the Use of Force | publisher = [[Martinus Nijhoff Publishers]] | year = 1986 | isbn = 978-90-247-3247-0}} Throughout its existence, it has controlled the Palestinian [[Arab Liberation Front]].{{cite book | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=RMANAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA58 58] | title = Guerrillas for Palestine | publisher = [[Taylor & Francis]] | year = 1976 | isbn =}} ===Libya=== {{main|Libyan Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party}} Following the [[1969 Libyan coup d'état|coup d'état of 1969]] against King [[Idris of Libya|Idris]], a new revolutionary government was established led by [[Muammar Gaddafi]]. The government was recognised as [[Nasserism|Nasserist]] because the new administration proclaimed its goal as "liberty, socialism and unity", rather than "unity, liberty, socialism" (the Ba'ath Party's slogan). This change in order was important because of the ideological split between the ba'athists and the Nasserists.{{cite book | author = Wright, John | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=NpcOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA123 123] | title = Libya: a Modern History | volume = | publisher = [[Taylor & Francis]] | year = 1981 | isbn = 0-7099-2727-4}} Following Gaddafi's revolution, several People's Committees were established. These committees (which at the beginning were led by the people) arrested several ba'athists.{{cite book | author = Wright, John | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=NpcOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA180 180] | title = Libya: a Modern History | volume = | publisher = [[Taylor & Francis]] | year = 1981 | isbn = 0-7099-2727-4}} Amr Taher Deghayes, founder of the Libyan Ba'ath branch, was later arrested by Gaddafi's security forces and died after three days in jail.{{cite book | author = Wright, John | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=NpcOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA277 277] | title = Libya: a Modern History | volume = | publisher = [[Taylor & Francis]] | year = 1981 | isbn = 0-7099-2727-4}} Deghayes' death allegedly sparked a large anti-government demonstration (which was crushed), followed by the imprisonment of several leading Ba'athists.{{cite book | author = Wright, John | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=NpcOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA281 281] | title = Libya: a Modern History | volume = | publisher = [[Taylor & Francis]] | year = 1981 | isbn = 0-7099-2727-4}} In 1982, a trial began in which 25 Libyan Ba'athists were charged with membership in an illegal organisation and they were freed after torture. The following year, they were re-tried on the same charge: three were sentenced to death and others to life in prison.{{cite book | author = Metz, Helen Chapin | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=aRNVYtHo63IC&pg=PA296 296] | title = Libya: a Country Study | volume = | publisher = [[Kessinger Publishing]] | year = 2004 | isbn = 1-4191-3012-9}} The arrests and trials of the 1980s led to the dissolution of the Libyan regional Ba'athist organisation.{{cite book | author = Leslie Simmons, Geoffrey | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=bepGPEkbL34C&pg=PA166 166] | title = Libya: The Struggle for Survival | volume = | publisher = [[Palgrave Macmillan]] | year = 1993 | isbn = 0-312-08997-X}} The [[Libyan National Movement]] (LNM), an [[Arab nationalism|Arab-nationalist]] organisation, was founded by [[Ba'athism|Ba'athist]] lawyer 'Umran Burweiss.{{cite book |author=Tachau, Frank |title=Political Parties of the Middle East and North Africa | location = Westport, Conn | publisher = [[Greenwood Press]] | year = 1994}} The LNM (still in existence) was originally financed by Iraqi Ba'athists{{cite book | page= [https://books.google.com/books?id=UDAWAQAAMAA 20] | title = The Middle East | volume= 111–12 | location = London | publisher = IC Magazines | year = 1984}} and produced relatively high-quality propaganda materials. For example, it issued audio cassettes which were smuggled into Libya with ''Sawt at-Talia'' during the 1980s. The organisation also produced broadcasts for Radio Baghdad.{{cite book |author1=Shaked, Haim |author2=Daniel Dishon | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=t32OO3DkDikC&pg=PA583 583] | title = Middle East Contemporary Survey | volume = 8 | year = 1983–84 | publisher = [[Moshe Dayan Center for Middle Eastern and African Studies]]}} ===Mauritania=== {{main|National Vanguard Party}} The first pro-Iraqi activities was in 1968, but it was organizationally established in 1972.{{cite web|url=http://themoornextdoor.files.wordpress.com/2011/07/overviewmaurba.pdf |title= An Overview of Ba'athist tendencies in Mauritania |publisher=The Moor Next Door |date=November 2010 |accessdate=12 July 2013}} The Mauritanian Ba'athist divide their history into two phases: founding (1976–1982) and deployment (1982–1990). There is little available information on the 1968–1970 period and Ba'athist activity started in earnest in the early 1970s. The party's first clandestine congress was held in 1976. They opposed the rule of [[Moktar Ould Daddah]] and used most of their early years in trying to infiltrate the ruling [[Mauritanian People's Party]] and state institutions. In the aftermath of the 1978 coup, the Ba'ath branch took the conscious decision of trying to recruit [[Haratin|Haratin people]]. They started publishing ''The Baʿth and the Haratine in Mauritania'' to help them in their quest. In the period 1978–1984, the party intensified its effort of recruiting members within the military establishment. The Ba'ath party was one of the most fervent supporters of the [[Arabization]] policies in Mauritania. Because of their efforts, Mohammed Yehdih Ould Breideleil, the Ba'ath leader, was appointed Minister of Information for a short period in 1984. Under the rule of Mohamed Khouna Ould Haidalla, the Ba'ath were harassed and in between 1982 and 1983 55 Ba'athists were arrested by the government. However, by 1986–1987 the Ba'ath had managed to infiltrate the officer corps and the enlisted ranks, making them a threat to Ould Haidalla and his rule. Ould Haidalla, with Saddam Hussein's approval, expelled and banned Ba'athist personnel in the military in 1988. With Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, the Ba'ath party lost its popular appeal and the financial aid from the Iraqi embassy dried up. By 1990, there was not much left of the original Ba'ath movement. Another party, the National Vanguard Party ({{lang-ar|حزب الطليعة الوطني|translit=Hizb Al-Taliyeh Al-Watani}}, {{lang-fr|Parti Avant-Garde nationale}} or PAGN), was founded in 1991 and it replaced the old Ba'ath movement which had disintegrated in 1990.{{cite book |author1=Lane, Jan-Erik |author2=Redissi, Hamadi |author3=Ṣaydāwī, Riyāḍ | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=UouRFVxywIQC&pg=PA217 217] | title = Religion and Politics: Islam and Muslim Civilization | volume = | publisher = [[Ashgate Publishing]] | year = 2009 | isbn = 0-7546-7418-5}} The Mauritanian Ba'ath Party remains the largest [[Arab nationalist]] political force in the country. The branch has maintained good relations with the Baghdad-based Ba'ath Party, even after Saddam Hussein's downfall following the 2003 invasion of Iraq. The party was able to field candidates for parliamentary seats during the [[Mauritanian parliamentary election, 1992|1992 parliamentary elections]] and was the only party (with the exception of the [[Republican Party for Democracy and Renewal]]) to field candidates for senate elections. However, the party secured only one percent of the vote nationwide and did not secure a seat in either Parliament or the senate. Kabry Ould Taleb Jiddou, the party's leader, was awarded the office of Secretary of State by the newly elected government because of his electoral campaign.{{cite book |author1=Banks, Arhur S. |author2=Muller, Thomas |author3=Overstreet, William | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=vXU_CplFBLYC&q=%22baathist%22+Pag&dq=%22baathist%22+Pag&hl=en&ei=kQjQTofcFcnk4QSX8LlV&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA 848] | title = Political Handbook of the World 2008 | volume = | publisher = [[CQ Press]] | year = 2008 | isbn = 0-87289-528-9}} The branch supports full [[Arabisation]] of the country, a view considered racist by critics. Ould Haidalla introduced an anti-ba'athist policy which continued under his successor, [[Maaouya Ould Sid'Ahmed Taya]]. However, the Mauritanian government supported Iraq during the [[Gulf War]] and Iraq–Mauritania relations became so close that (inaccurate) rumours circulated internationally that Saddam's family had taken refuge in the country following the American invasion. Repression against the ba'athists has not been reduced. In 2003, several ba'athists were jailed on suspicion of trying to overthrow the government.{{cite book | author = Seddon, David | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=qmYMy1Ls8ucC&pg=PA87 87] | title = A Political and Economic Dictionary of the Middle East | volume = | publisher = [[Taylor & Francis]] | year = 2004 | isbn = 1-85743-212-6}} A reason for the close relationship between Iraq and Mauritania was the strength of the Mauritanian ba'athist party.{{cite book |author1=Thomas, Caroline |author2=Wilkin, Peter | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=e8MrsaMgILsC&pg=PA114 114] | title = Globalization, Human Security, and the African Experience | volume = | publisher = [[Lynne Rienner Publishers]] | year = 1999 | isbn = 1-55587-699-4}} The party was banned in 1999 following the restoration of bilateral relations with [[Israel]].{{cite book |author1=East, Roger |author2=Thomas, Richard | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=Mz–fXRsedPMC&pg=PA345 345] | title = Profiles of People in Power: The World's Government Leaders | volume = | publisher = [[Routledge]] | year = 1999 | isbn = 1-85743-126-X}} The National Vanguard Party was accused of developing plans in collaboration with the Iraqi government to foment unrest in the country.{{cite book |author1=Banks, Arhur S. |author2=Muller, Thomas |author3=Overstreet, William | page = [https://books.google.com/books?ei=7_bPTouNCqzQ4QSe8uQf&ct=result&id=vXU_CplFBLYC&dq=%22national+vanguard+party%22+mauritania+baath&q=%22national+vanguard+party%22#search_anchor 848] | title = Political Handbook of the World 2008 | volume = | publisher = [[CQ Press]] | year = 2008 | isbn = 0-87289-528-9}} Mohamed Ould Abdellahi Ould Eyye, the party's leader, was arrested in 2003 after a large anti-government protest demanding that the government break off relations with Israel and the United States and aid Saddam Hussein. He and 13 other ba'athists were arrested by government forces and the party's headquarters were raided in May.{{cite book | author = [[Europa Publications]] | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=jj4J–AXGDaQC&pg=PA702 702] | title = Africa South of the Sahara 2004 | volume = | publisher = [[Routledge]] | year = 2003 | isbn = 1-85743-183-9}} Another pro-Iraqi Ba'ath party did take its place, the Party for Work and National Unity ({{lang-fr| Parti pour le Travail et l'Uniti Nationale}}, abbreviated PTUN). However, while PTUN is close to the Iraqi Ba'ath branch, the group is small and largely inactive.{{cite web|url=http://www.cablegatesearch.net/cable.php?id=06NOUAKCHOTT568&q=baath |title= Summary Of Political Parties And Coalitions In Mauritania, May 2006 |publisher=[[Cablegate]] |date=15 May 2006 |accessdate=10 July 2013}} ===Palestine=== {{further|Arab Liberation Front}} {{infobox |above=Palestinian branch |abovestyle=background-color: #efefef |headerstyle=background-color: #efefef |image1= |label2=Founded |data2=1969 |label3=Secretary-General |data3=Rakad Salem |label4=Newspaper |data4=''[[Sawt al-Jamahir]]'' |label5=Homepage |data5=[http://alfpalestine.org/ alfpalestine.org] }} A disorganised pro-Iraqi Ba'ath guerilla movement existed before the establishment of the [[Arab Liberation Front]] (ALF).{{cite book | author = Anderson, Bette Signe | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=HXNnEkLRtSoC&pg=PA203 203] | title = Nationalist Voices in Jordan: The Street and the State | volume = | publisher = [[University of Texas Press]] | year = 2005 | isbn = 978-0-292-70625-5}} The ALF was established in 1969 at a National Congress of the Iraqi-dominated Ba'ath Party to weaken the hold [[al-Sa'iqa]], the pro-Syrian Ba'ath organisation in Palestine had over the ba'athist movement. In contrast to al-Sa'iqa, the ALF never had access to a large recruitment pool. There were few Palestinians in Iraq, and the Palestinians living in Iraq were generally well-educated. Because of this, ALF could not and would never have the same degree of influence over the Palestinian movement as al-Sa'iqa did. This caused the ALF to be controlled by the pro-Iraq Ba'ath movement, thus weakening its effectiveness and influence, but saving it from infighting between [[Palestinian nationalism|Palestinianists]] and Ba'athists (a problem in al-Sa'iqa). However, the ALF's influence weakened periodically during its history due to infighting in the pro-Iraq Ba'ath movement. Because of the control the pro-Iraq Ba'ath movement had over the ALF, the ALF always held a pro-Iraqi position in the [[Palestinian Liberation Front]] (PLO). The ALF was a founding member of the [[Rejectionist Front]] in 1974, rejecting the [[PLO's Ten Point Program]]. Abdel-Wahhab Kayyali (a member of the [[Executive Committee of the Palestine Liberation Organization|PLO Executive Committee]]) froze his seat on the committee in protest, instead of following the example (resignation) of the Rejectionist Front.{{cite book | author = Cobban, Helena | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=wwntdx2IFAEC&pg=PA163 163] | title = The Palestinian Liberation Organisation: People, Power, and Politics | volume = | publisher = [[Cambridge University Press]] | year = 1984 | isbn = 978-0-521-27216-2}} While Palestinians generally believe in [[pan-Arabism]], [[Arab nationalism]] and [[socialism]] (principles of the ALF), they have generally opted for the [[Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine]].{{cite book | author = Cobban, Helena | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=wwntdx2IFAEC&pg=PA164 164] | title = The Palestinian Liberation Organisation: People, Power, and Politics | volume = | publisher = [[Cambridge University Press]] | year = 1984 | isbn = 978-0-521-27216-2}} The [[invasion of Iraq]] toppled the Iraqi-dominated Ba'ath Party, headquartered in Baghdad. This weakened the movement and since the [[Iraqi military]] coordinated much of the ALF's activities the ALF has also been considerably weakened.{{cite book | author = Baracskay, Daniel | page = [https://books.google.com/books?id=UIJDreLroswC&pg=PA58 58] | title = The Palestine Liberation Organization: Terrorism and Prospects for Peace in the Holy Land | volume = | publisher = [[ABC-CLIO]] | year = 2011 | isbn = 978-0-313-38151-5}} The ALF's first leader was Zaid Haydar from the Jordanian Ba'ath branch. Other leaders include [[Munif al-Razzaz]], Abd al-Rahim Ahmad and Mahmud Isma'il. Most recently, it was led by [[Rakad Salem]] and headquartered in [[Ramallah]], [[West Bank]]. [[Israeli Defence Forces]] arrested Salem in October 2002.{{cite book |author1=Matter, Philip |author2=Fischbach, Michael | pages = [https://books.google.com/books?id=GkbzYoZtaJMC&pg=PA51 51–52] | title = Encyclopedia of the Palestinians | volume = | publisher = [[Infobase Publishing]] | year = 2005 | isbn = 978-0-8160-5764-1}} Shahir Abu Shahut, former leader of the Jordanian Ba'ath branch, led the Ba'ath branch in Palestine from 1970 to 1975 from Baghdad. ===Sudan=== {{Main|Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Region of Sudan}} The Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Country of Sudan is the regional branch of the Ba'ath Party in Sudan. Kamal Bolad was the Regional Secretary in 1989{{cite book |author=Lain, Donald Ray |pages=58–60 |title=Dictionary of the African Left: Parties, Movements and Groups |publisher=[[Dartmouth College Press|Dartmouth]] |year=1989 |isbn=1-85521-014-2}} and Taiseer Mutassir was the Regional Secretary in 1990. While the branch has always been small, accounting for an estimated 1,000 members in 2003, it has been able to have a bigger impact than what its meager membership numbers would suggest, mostly due to Iraqi financing of the branch.{{cite web|url=http://www.cablegatesearch.net/cable.php?id=03KHARTOUM374&q=ba-ath |title= Return Of Sudanese Ba'athists |publisher=[[Cablegate]] |date=30 April 2003 |accessdate=11 July 2013}} After collaborating with the Arab nationalist Sudanese government for years, the Ba'ath Party broke off relations and became an opposition party in 1990—this would have disturbed Iraq if Sudan had not supported it during the [[Gulf War|1991 Gulf crisis]].{{cite book|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=L-mBF9tAeGQC&pg=PA210 210]|title= Darfur and the International Community: The Challenges of Conflict Resolution in Sudan|publisher=[[I.B.Tauris]]|author=Barltrop, Richard|isbn= 978-1-84511-977-5|year=2010}} In 1990, the party was composed largely of students who had studied in [[Ba'athist Iraq]]. The party, which was small in 1990, was influential in certain sectors, was opposed to the [[National Islamic Front]] and was staunchly [[secularism|secularist]]. Members have historically been torn between the Ba'ath and other secular party movements, such as the [[Sudanese Communist Party|Sudanese communists]]. Because of Saddam Hussein's amicable relationship with the [[Revolutionary Command Council for National Salvation]], the body ruling Sudan, the Ba'ath branched was oppressed by the authorities.{{cite web|url=http://www.cablegatesearch.net/cable.php?id=90KHARTOUM3477&q=baath |title= Sudan And The Arabs: Possibly Step-sisters; Certainly Not Brothers |publisher=[[Cablegate]] |date=1 April 1990 |accessdate=11 July 2013}} Later in 1990, 26 Ba'athi military officers were executed in [[Khartoum]] after a failed military coup. In 2002, a group led by Mohamad Ali Jadein broke away from the branch and established the independent [[Sudanese Ba'ath Party]], which has no affiliation with neither the pro-Iraq Ba'ath movement nor the [[Ba'ath Party (Syrian-dominated faction)|pro-Syrian Ba'ath movement]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sudanvisiondaily.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=1100 |title=Wide Reactions to Jadein Group Statement by Baathists |work=Sudan Vision Daily |accessdate=26 February 2012 |date=April 10, 2003 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061118112036/http://www.sudanvisiondaily.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=1100 |archivedate=18 November 2006 |df= }} The following year, after the invasion of Iraq 80 Sudanese Ba'athists return to Sudan under the condition that they would stay out of politics. ===Syria=== {{Expand section|date=June 2014}} The Syrian branch of the party supported the [[Muslim Brotherhood of Syria|Muslim Brotherhood]] during the [[Islamist uprising in Syria|Islamist uprising]] against the Syrian Ba'ath government.{{cite web|url=http://www.cablegatesearch.net/cable.php?id=85DAMASCUS1314&q=ba-th |title= The Syrian Muslim Brotherhood |publisher=[[Cablegate]] |date=26 February 1985 |accessdate=12 July 2013}} ===Tunisia=== {{main|Tunisian Ba'ath Movement}} The first Ba'athist branch in Tunisia, then under the [[Ba'ath Party|unified Ba'ath Party]], was established in 1955, but the Ba'ath Party was outlawed under [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali]]. Following the [[Tunisian Revolution]], the Tunisian Ba'ath Movement ({{lang-ar|حركة البعث التونسي}} ''Haraket Al-Ba'ath Al-Tounisi''; [[French language|French]]: ''Mouvement Baath tunisien'') was established at its First Congress on 3–5 June 2011 and legally registered on 22 January 2011. However, ba'athists have been active in underground politics since the 1950s. The Ba'ath Movement celebrated the fifth anniversary of the [[execution of Saddam Hussein|death]] of [[Saddam Hussein]]. Omar Othman Belhadj, Secretary-General of the Executive Committee of the Ba'ath Movement, said that "Hussein’s execution was symbolic, they did not kill a person but rather the ideas he represented and fought for. Hussein was killed for being against colonization and for being a defender of Arab unity and independence of Arab countries". He further noted that he did not support killing [[Muammar Gaddafi]], saying that Gaddafi had a right to a fair trial like anyone else.{{cite web|url=http://www.tunisia-live.net/2012/01/04/tunisian-baath-party-celebrates-5th-anniversary-of-saddam-husseins-death/|publisher=Tunisia-live.net|title=Tunisian Baath Party Celebrates 5th Anniversary of Saddam Hussein’s Death|date=4 January 2012|accessdate=19 February 2012|author=Ajmi, Sana|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120310042933/http://www.tunisia-live.net/2012/01/04/tunisian-baath-party-celebrates-5th-anniversary-of-saddam-husseins-death/|archive-date=2012-03-10|dead-url=yes|df=}} Omar once told a journalist, "the Syrian regime has turned against the Ba'ath and is no longer Ba'athist one".{{cite web|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/09/23/168313.html|publisher=[[Al Arabiya]]|title= Tunisian Baathists have strong standing: party leader|date=23 September 2011|accessdate=23 February 2012}} The party does not support Syria's expulsion from the [[Arab League]] and asserts that foreign nations should play a neutral role in the [[Syrian Civil War]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tunisia-live.net/2011/11/13/tunisian-political-parties-respond-to-the-suspension-of-syria-from-the-arab-league/|publisher=Tunisia-live.net|title= Tunisian Political Parties respond to the suspension of Syria from the Arab League|date=13 November 2011|accessdate=19 February 2012|author=Ajmi, Sana}} On 4 February 2012, the Executive Committee of the Ba'ath Movement released a communiqué condemning the provisional Tunisian government's expulsion of the Syrian ambassador. The Ba'ath Movement expressed solidarity with the Syrian protesters and condemned the shooting of unarmed demonstrators. The committee predicted that the Syrian ambassador's expulsion would militarise the conflict, mobilising Arab opinion against the government and leading to military intervention.{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201202062108.html|publisher=AllAfrica.com|title= Tunisia: Baath Party Condemns President's Decision to Expel Syrian Ambassador|author=Ajmi, Sana|date=5 February 2012|accessdate=19 February 2012}} After the revolution, the Arab Democratic Vanguard Party emerged as second "Iraqi" Baathist Party in Tunisia. Its membership is younger and its political position more at the left of the historically Baath Movement and is headed by Kheireddine Souabni and Ahmed Seddik. The Ba'ath Movement is a member of the [[Popular Front (Tunisia)|Popular Front]],{{cite web|url=http://www.muslimnews.co.uk/news/news.php?article=24875 |publisher=MuslimNews.co.uk |title=Tunisia: Splintered history of the Tunisian Left |date=10 February 2013 |accessdate=22 February 2013 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} a communist-dominated front with strong popular backing.{{cite web|url=http://www.tunivisions.net/41491/222/149/tunisie-sondage-ennahdha-et-nidaa-tounes-en-tete-des-intentions-de-vote.html |publisher=Tunivisions.net |title=Tunisie, Sondage : Ennahdha et Nidaa Tounes en tête des intentions de vote |language=French |date=February 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2013 |author=[[Staff writer]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130224061331/http://www.tunivisions.net/41491/222/149/tunisie-sondage-ennahdha-et-nidaa-tounes-en-tete-des-intentions-de-vote.html |archivedate=24 February 2013 |df= }} ===Yemen=== {{main|National Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Yemen Region}} The National Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Yemen Region ({{lang-ar|حزب البعث العربي الاشتراكي القومي - قطر اليمن}} ''Hizb Al-Ba'ath Al-Arabi Al-Ishtiraki Al-Qawmi – Qutr Al-Yaman''){{cite web| author = [[Staff writer]] | publisher = National Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Yemen Region | script-title=ar:قيم البعث وعبقرية القائد الشهيد صدام حسين تجسدا يوم استشهاده |trans-title=Values of the Baath and the genius of the martyred leader Saddam Hussein's martyrdom day incarnation | date = 29 December 2010 | accessdate = 18 February 2012 | language = Arabic | url = http://www.almansore.com/Art.php?id=21811 }} is led by Qassem Salam Said as Secretary of the Regional Command while Abdulwahid Hawash serves as Deputy Secretary.{{cite web| author = al-Qiri, Mohammad | work = [[Yemen Observer]] | title = Third Yemeni Ba’ath party planned | date = 7 February 2009 | accessdate = 18 February 2012 | url = http://www.yobserver.com/local-news/10015730.html }} It publishes the newspaper ''Al-Ehyaa Al-'Arabi'' ({{lang-ar|لإحياء العربي}}, English: ''Arabic Renaissance'').{{cite web | author = [[Staff writer]] | publisher = [[United Nations Development Programme]]. [[Arab parliament]] | trans-title = Arab political parties: Yemen: the Arab Socialist Baath Party, the National | script-title = ar:الأحزاب السياسية العربية: اليمن: حزب البعث العربي الاشتراكي القومي | date = 23 October 2009 | accessdate = 18 February 2012 | language = Arabic | url = http://www.arabparliaments.org/arabic/whatwedo/parties.aspx?cid=22&pid=206 | title = Archived copy | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120402042129/http://www.arabparliaments.org/arabic/whatwedo/parties.aspx?cid=22&pid=206 | archive-date = 2012-04-02 | dead-url = yes | df = }} The party carried out clandestine political activity until 1990 and was registered as the National Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party on 10 February 1997. It had initially sought to register as the Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party in 1995, but that name was given by the authorities to the [[Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Yemen Region|pro-Syria Ba'athist party]].{{cite web| author = [[Staff writer]] | publisher= National Information Center. [[Government of Yemen]] |trans-title=Political parties in the Republic of Yemen | script-title=ar:الأحزاب السياسية في الجمهورية اليمنية | date = | accessdate = 18 February 2012 | language = Arabic | url = http://www.yemen-nic.info/contents/Politics/detail.php?ID=8437 }} Politically, the party is allied with the ruling [[General People's Congress (Yemen)|General People's Congress]] and during the 2011 [[Arab Spring]] this position caused an internal split.{{cite web| author = [[Staff writer]] | publisher= Assafir Press |trans-title=Temporary leadership of the Baath Arab Socialist National freeze peace and fragmentation of the party accused | script-title=ar:قيادة مؤقتة لحزب البعث العربي الاشتراكي القومي تجمد سلام وتتهمه بتفتيت الحزب | date = 9 May 2011 | accessdate = 18 February 2012 | language = Arabic | url = http://www.yemen-nic.info/contents/Politics/detail.php?ID=8437 }} In March 2011, it was reported that the [[Hodeidah]] branch of the party had sided with the uprising after violent attacks on protesters in the city.{{cite web| author = [[Staff writer]] | publisher= Felix News |trans-title=National Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party in Hodeidah breaks its relationship with the ruling party after the massacre of peaceful protesters in Sanaa | script-title=ar:حزب البعث العربي الاشتراكي القومي بالحديدة يفك الارتباط بالحزب الحاكم بعد مجزرة صنعاء بحق المعتصمين سلمياً | date = 30 March 2011 | accessdate = 18 February 2012 | language = Arabic | url = http://www.felixnews.com/news-10557.html }} The party contested the [[Yemeni parliamentary election, 1993|1993 parliamentary election]] in alliance with the pro-Syrian Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party, winning seven seats. After the election, relations between the two Ba'athist groups soured and they contested further elections separately. The party contested the [[Yemeni parliamentary election, 1997|1997 parliamentary election]] (failing to win any seats) and called for a boycott of the [[Yemeni presidential election, 1999|1999 presidential election]]. Said, the branch leader, was sued by the Ministry of Information in February 2000 over an article criticising [[Saudi Arabia]].{{cite web | author = [[United States Government]] | url = https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2000/nea/826.htm | title = Yemen: Country Reports on Human Rights Practices | location = | publisher = [[Department of State (United States)|Department of State]] | date = 23 February 2001 | accessdate = 30 November 2011 }} In the [[Yemeni parliamentary election, 2003|2003 parliamentary elections]], the party obtained 23,745 votes (0.4 percent of the national vote) and again failed to re-enter parliament. However, it won two district-council seats in the 2006 local council elections.{{cite web| author = [[Staff writer]] | publisher= Almotamar.net | title = President Saleh calls on local councils to hold a meeting on 1 November | date = 18 October 2006 | accessdate = 18 February 2012 | url = http://www.almotamar.net/en/1253.htm }} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== revision.text:
[[Image:Mexico.Tlax.Cacaxtla.04.jpg|right|thumb|250px|The ''Gran Basamento'', protected by its sheet-metal roof]][[Image:Mexico.Tlax.Cacaxtla.02.jpg|right|250px|thumb|View over the top of the ''Gran Basamento'']] '''Cacaxtla''' ({{IPA-nah|kaˈkaʃtɬaːn}}) is an [[archaeology|archaeological]] site located near the southern border of the [[States of Mexico|Mexican state]] of [[Tlaxcala]]. It was a sprawling palace containing vibrantly colored murals painted in unmistakable Maya style. The nearby site of Xochitecatl was a more public ceremonial complex associated with Cacaxtla. Cacaxtla and Xochitecatl prospered 650-900 CE, probably controlling important trade routes through the region with an enclave population of no more than 10,000 people.
==History== Cacaxtla was the capital of region inhabited by the [[:es:Olmeca-xicalanca|Olmeca-Xicalanca]] people. The origins of the Olmeca-Xicalanca are not known with certainty, but they are assumed to come from the [[Gulf of Mexico|Gulf coast]] region, and were perhaps [[Maya civilization|Maya]] settlers who arrived in this part of central Mexico around 400 CE.
The term "Olmeca-Xicalanca" was first mentioned by Tlaxcalan historian [[Diego Muñoz Camargo]] at the end of the 16th century. This historian described Cacaxtla as the principal settlement of the “Olmeca”, although what we today refer to as the Olmec culture ended ~400 [[Common Era|BCE]], that is, almost 800 years earlier.
After the fall of the nearby city [[Cholula (Mesoamerican site)|Cholula]] (ca. 650 - 750) — in which the ''Cacaxtlecas'' might have been involved — Cacaxtla became the hegemonic power in this part of the Tlaxcala–Puebla valley. Warriors from Cacaxtla appear to have taken over Cholula for a time, but they were ultimately expelled by the Toltecs. Its ascendancy came to an end around 900 CE and, by 1000, the city had been abandoned.
===Modern history of the site=== The site was rediscovered in 1974 by looters, but quickly came to the attention of archaeologists that same year. Archaeologists Eduardo Merlo Juárez, Diana Lopez-Sotomayor and Daniel Molina-Feal dedicated over six years of their life excavating the site. The first work to be done in the area consisted on clearing the original tunnel opened by the looters, Archeologist Diana Lopez-Sotomayor, later appointed project manager, recalled her first view of the life-sized characters depicted in the murals as an overwhelming experience. As further figures appeared on the mural, the area of excavation had to be enlarged and several constructive stages were discovered. The first area to be excavated was the main mural, known as the "Gran Basamento", and the immediate purpose of the work was to protect and secure the murals and other structures from the weather and looters.
==The Site== [[File:Cacaxtla pyramid mound no. 1.jpg|thumb|Cacaxtla pyramid mound no. 1]]
The centre of the city of Cacaxtla was the 200-metre-long, 25-metre-high ''Gran Basamento'' – a natural platform offering a fine defensive position and commanding views over the surrounding terrain. The city's main religious and civil buildings were located on this platform, as were the residences of the priest class. Several other smaller pyramids and temple bases stand in the vicinity of the main platform.
Because Cacaxtla's main ''basamento'' was not excavated until the 1980s, many of the original coloured wall decorations have been preserved and can be appreciated [[in situ#Archaeology|in situ]] by visitors to the site. Of particular interest is the fact that most of the murals seem to combine the symbology of [[Altiplano]] cultures with influences from the [[Maya civilization|Maya]], making Cacaxtla unique in this regard.
==Battle Mural (Mural de la Batalla)== The most famous of Cacaxtla's preserved paintings is the "Battle Mural", or ''Mural de la batalla'', located in the northern plaza of the ''basamento''. Dating from prior to 700, it is placed on the sloping limestone wall of a temple base and is split in two by a central staircase. It depicts two groups of warriors locked in battle: on the one side are jaguar warriors, armed with spears, obsidian knives, and round shields, who are locked in battle with an army of bird warriors (some of whom are shown naked and in various stages of dismemberment). [[File:Cacaxtla Battle Mural (left).jpg|center|thumb|500px|Cacaxtla Battle Mural (left)]] [[File:Cacaxtla Battle Mural (right).jpg|center|thumb|500px|Cacaxtla Battle Mural (right)]]
==Priestly Attire (Vestidos de Sacerdotes)== Cacaxtla conserves the oldest mural painting featuring a human figure and symbols from other cultures (Teotihuacan, Maya, Mixtec and Totonac). These paintings portray the bird man and the feline man, possibly ruler - priests of the Olmecs Xicalancas who inhabited Cacaxtla between the years 600 and 900 AD. The bird man is associated with Quetzalcoatl, the generous deity who taught people the arts and agriculture. The feline man is associated with the rains that fertilize the earth. [[File:VestidosDeSacerdotes(Hombre-Ave).jpg|thumb|150px|Bird Man (Hombre - ave)]] [[File:VestidosDeSacerdotes(Hombre-Felino).jpg|thumb|150px|Feline Man (Hombre - felino)]]
==Venus Temple (Templo de Venus)== The Venus Temple that is also located underneath the roof contains two murals on two columns of two figures. On the right column, there is a male figure with a mask covering his face. He wears a skirt with the Venus symbol on the front and has a scorpion tail. On the left, a fragment of the other figure is visible, probably representing a woman with a skirt also bearing a Venus symbol. The presence of Venus on the garments of the figures and their representation around both of them indicate that the murals allude to some astronomical phenomenon or calendrical data associated with the planet Venus, which at that time was related to warfare and sacrifice.
<gallery widths="100px"> File:MuralDelTemploDeVenus(left).jpg|Left column File:MuralDelTemploDeVenus(right).jpg|Right column </gallery>
==Mural del Templo Rojo== The Mural del Templo Rojo is located at the Governors' Room (Las Habitactiones de los Gobernantes). It is located in the staircase leading to the room, and only one side is visible to the public. The other side of the staircase is not facing a public walkway, but is displayed as a reproduction in the corresponding museum building. [[File:Caxatla Mural Del Templo Rojo.jpg|center|thumb|Mural del Templo Rojo (left side)]]
==Visiting the site== [[Image:Cacaxtla03.jpg|right|100px|thumb|upright Priestly Attire, figure on right doorjamb]] The archaeological site is maintained by the government's [[National Institute of Anthropology and History]] (INAH) and is open Tuesday to Sunday, from 8:00 to 17:30. The admission is 65 MXN on weekdays, and free on Sunday for Mexican Nationals. Permission to record videos costs another $50 MXN while photography is free.<ref>Further information: www.dti.inah.gob.mx</ref>
Another nearby site associated with Cacaxtla is Xochitecatl which was a more public ceremonial complex.
==See also== *[[Xochitecatl]], a neighbouring archaeological site, approximately 1 km to the west.
